children.value:
Introduction

This is a template for blog posts. This website is built from Gatsby framework and the way of styling is slightly different from HTML/CSS. You can write posts use markdown or/and HTML/CSS (preferable, because some syntax of markdown doesn't work). A copy of this blog file is available here.
If you want to preview the post while you're writing, then you'll need to setup a gatsby development environment in order to preview the website.
For Windows users, Download and install the latest Node.js version from
. (You might also need to download Visual Studio installer to install node.js development tools).
Fork this repository and open up your Git Bash (and navigate to a directory you want to place the site) and run
Create a new local branch with commands
(create a new branch from master), and

(switch to new branch).
Now make any commits you wish to.
NOTE: At step 4, If you have write permission for the origin repository, then you could just create a new branch in the origin repository and clone it.
installed then just clone the repository into your computer and under the repository you would need to use Git Bash to run

If you cloned a while a ago, fetch the latest commits from origin repository:

git checkout master
git pull upstream master

.
Now you can view the site at
. Any changes you made to posts locally will be updated instantly on preview. Press
if you want to stop it running locally.
To contribute, raise an issue on GitHub or make a pull request that adds or modifies files in the

directory. 
You will probably want to install Gatsby so that you can test your contribution before submitting it. Steps on below assuming you've setup everything mentioned above.
Make a new directory under the
directory, give a name (e.g. a keyword relevant to your post).
(or with .md extension, but we recommend use .mdx because it’s a superset of Markdown syntax that also supports importing, exporting, and JSX.
-> At the very beginning of your index file, you have the following parameters to specify:

---
title: "This is a template for posts"
author: ["A", "B"]   
date: "2020-03-06"                    //Please use Y-M-D format required by mdx syntax, if the post belongs to "Events" category, then probably use the event date rather than the written date
description: "Shown at blog page"
category: "Articles"
tag: ["blog", "test"]
thumbnail: ./image.jpg                // an image to use for your post thumbnail
template:                             // optional, if set to "custom", you would need to design your own post page except from header and footer of the website.
---
-> Wrap parameters with triple hyphens. Use double quotation marks for all text, use square brackets in parameters with two or more items.
-> Then add content to the file.
Copy any other resources required for the post to the current directory. For example, if you want to include an image
then the file path for it would be
. Sections below will tell you how to embed images and videos.
Now create a pull request. If it comes from a fork repository,

.
If it comes from a branch in origin repository,
If you do not want to setup the environment, you can write a post by upload index.mdx file and any resources related to the post on Github too.

<div>
There are many ways to add styles to your md/mdx elements, in here we listed two methods to do this.
Use the style attribute as usual with slightly different syntax:

In HTML we normally style a div tag like this:
Write something
----------------------- In Gatsby we transform it into:
Write something
For any declaration in HTML with hyphen, in Gatsby we remove the hyphen and capitalise the letter after the hyphen.
framework therefore you can style elements by applying
to see available classes you can utilise.

// In Gatsby, class is replaced by className An example of using tailwindCSS

TAILwindCSS

text-3xl: text size with 3xl. text-gray-500: text color set to be gray with transparency of 500 (50% probably). mb-24: bottom margin with size 24.
Of course you can also add your own class, just need to make sure all classes you've created need to be place in the file

. Specificity is important, 
to avoid your classes being override by other styling plugins, add
before each class. Alternatively, use style attribute.
To add inline code, surround your code by single backtick.
For a code block, use triple backticks.

1```html
code block
1```

1 is for illustration, remove it in practice.
You can also specify what programming language after first triple backticks.

Files

To make a file available to readers, place the file under the post directory and add something like this:

export const _frontmatter = {"author":["Y.L Weng"],"title":"How to upload a blog post","thumbnail":"./temp.jpg","description":"This is a template for blog post.","date":"2020-03-06","category":["Articles"],"tag":["Blog"],"template":null}
